key_points: NYC Law Department's computer system has been down for approximately three days due to a hacking incident.
The FBI and NYC's Cyber Command office are analyzing the hack, with motives still being investigated.
Hackers have not yet demanded a ransom, but officials, including John Miller (NYPD's deputy commissioner), do not rule out the possibility.
Investigators have identified the malware used in the hack, noting it as familiar and are tracing it back to the hackers.
The Law Department has been using outdated software, including Windows 7 and Microsoft Office 2010, which are no longer supported by Microsoft.
Warnings about vulnerabilities in the Law Department's computer systems were previously issued but not adequately addressed.
Since the hack, Law Department employees cannot access the system remotely or use work emails.
Efforts to contain the hack prevented it from spreading to other systems, but the Law Department's operations have been severely impacted.
An audit of the Law Department's computer systems was completed last month, with findings not publicly disclosed due to security concerns.
This incident is part of a wider trend of hack attacks on American infrastructure, with President Biden expected to address such issues with Russian President Putin.
spokespersons: John Miller (NYPD's deputy commissioner of intelligence and counterterrorism)
